headline: Turkey Pot Pie
description: Cooked turkey, celery, carrots, onions, and potatoes in a creamy homemade sauce are baked in flaky pastry in this classic pot pie recipe.
name: Turkey Pot Pie
recipeIngredient: 1 recipe pastry for a (10 inch) double crust pie

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Roll out bottom pie crust and place in the 10 inch pie pan and set aside.

Place 2 tablespoons of the butter in a large skillet. Add the onion, celery, carrots, parsley, oregano, salt and pepper. Cook and stir until the vegetables are soft. Stir in the bouillon and water. Bring mixture to a boil. Stir in the potatoes, and cook until tender but still firm.

In a medium saucepan, melt the remaining 2 tablespoons butter. Stir in the turkey and flour. Add the milk, and heat through. Stir the turkey mixture into the vegetable mixture, and cook until thickened. Pour mixture into the unbaked pie shell. Roll out the top crust, and place on top of filling. Flute edges, and make 4 slits in the top crust to let out steam.
Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce oven temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) and continue baking for 20 minutes, or until crust is golden brown.

review.reviewBody: Family favorite
Very versatile - I added some extra spices that were already recommended in other comments
I purposefully skipped the pie crust and served it like a soup with biscuits on the side. I accidentally left out the potatoes, though.
Just made this. Only change I added peas and my inner Julia Child added some wine. (Don’t do that made it too runny. Just drink the wine)
OMG!!! This was so good. Making it a yearly after Thanksgiving tradition.
We are a vegetarian household. Made it without the turkey, and added some shredded cheese and panko as a topping before top layer of crust.
I added some zuchini I had on hand. The pie was a big hit! Everyone loves a two-crust meat pie.
What a great way to cook leftovers family loved it
This is my goto recipe after Thanksgiving holiday. It always comes out great. Don't forget to add an egg wash to your pie crust. It helps it tur out golden brown.
I made it exactly as the recipe goes but added in some peas and corn. Tired out amazing.
I love it. Been looking for a great turkey pie recipe for years. I would thicken it a bit more next time I make it but it was very flavorful and will definetely make it again.
Nice flavour- we’d use more meat and fewer potatoes next time
Added frozen peas and poultry seasoning. A great hit with family.
Loved it. Will make this again.
This is a great recipe for turkey leftovers. It also freezes well. My family loved it.
Family really loved this dish - comfort food! I added peas to the recipe and have made it with turkey and chicken.

Love this recipe! I've made it several times over the years. Sometimes I buy a chicken at supermarket, have dinner and then have the leftovers to make this pot pie. Works our perfect. I've given the recipe to my daughters and many other people. I do not use the oregano but that is a person preference.
It’s very good!!!

I made my own crust with 2 1/4 c four 1tsp salt.5 cups milk .5 cups oil mix flour and salt put both .5 cups li quid into 1 cup don't mix pour into flour mix thoroughly make into two balls wrap in plastic wrap put in fridge for 15 minutes. while crust is in fridge I made filling per recipe except I omitted the potatoes and added a cup of frozen peas and 4 minced garlic cloves. I also used 3 cups of Turkey. Rolled out bottom crust poured in filling topped with upper crust. It was fantastic. Didn't take too long and I can't wait to eat the leftovers

Followed the recipe exactly, and we didn't care for the flavor or the consistency. I made the crust using No Fail Pie Crust 1 from this site. The crust was OK but would taste better if I had used butter flavored Shortening. We will likely not make this again, but will try some other recipes on this site for leftover turkey (soups, stews, hash, salad, lettuce cups, chili, etc).

Made this a couple of days after Christmas and wasn't sure picky hubby would eat this........and he loved it! I made 8 individual pies and we are having this for supper tonight. I made stock from the turkey carcass and will use some to make gravy - we both like gravy on this.
Tasty!
Just used a little less spices!!

This is a great tasting pie! I omitted the broth and flour mixture and used cream of mushroom soup (2 cans) with 1 cup of milk. Also used already boiled potatoes left over from my potato salad so cut time on cooking potatoes. Hubby gives it a thumbs up ??
This was delicious. My husband said "Home Run". The only thing I did different was to bake it the entire 35 minutes at 425 degrees. No soggy crust on the bottom that was reported previously..
Made using Pillsbury pie crust. This is a fabulous turkey pie.
Went together easily, very tasty.

I made this last night....best pot pie ever.
Thank you!
Used a cast iron skillet and precooked the bottom crust as someone else mentioned. It came out perfect!!! Definitely adding this to the family favorite rotation.

My husband has been after me for years to use the leftover turkey from Christmas in a pot pie like his mom. This recipe made is so easy and it tasted wonderful. I will be making this recipe more often.

Took several short cuts by using frozen peas and carrots as well as all chicken broth as opposed to boullion and water. I also used Pillsbury pre-made crusts and baked it at 350 for about 35 minutes. It turned out fantastic!
Delicious. Didn't change a thing! Made it again to see if it was as good as the first, and it was. Yummy
I made this following Thanksgiving. It was really easy to put together. My husband loved it!
My husband, son and I LOVED this recipe. I did add mushrooms and a little poultry seasoning.

Fabulous recipe! I bought two frozen 9" pie crusts. I baked one crust for 8 minutes, as other reviewers suggested. For the veggies, i used 2 cups of a frozen mix of green beans, carrots, peas, and corn (heated in microwave 1st). Instead of the 2 cups of water with chicken bouillion, I used 2 cups of leftover turkey gravy. I used almond milk instead of dairy milk. Recipe was awesome!!!

A great way to use thanksgiving turkey leftovers! I blended the turkey into small chunks to spread it evenly throughout, and I used a premade pie crust (broke college student on a budget!). I broke the crust into pieces and mixed it in. Delicious!
My family had a lot of praise for this recipe.
Great recipe, easy to follow.

I made this with what I had on hand. Used ground turkey, pre steamed mixed veggies, turkey gravy and a small amount of mashed potatoes as a thickener. Used Italian seasoning, salt and pepper. Baked the bottomed of the crust to as void a soggy crust. There’s only 2 slices left! It was a hit :)

I used chicken stock I had already. I used someone's suggestion to slightly cook the carrots first. I threw in veggies from my fridge like mushrooms and leftover corn. And I brushed an egg wash for the top crust.

Very easy recipe and very tasty! I love that it’s simple ingredients. It was a great way to use up last years thanksgiving turkey! I ended up doubling the recipe which may contribute to prep time but it did take me more than 20 minutes with all the cutting of veggies. I took a shortcut and got the frozen carrot/pea mixture which helped save some time and added a little extra element to it. I’ll definitely make this again. I followed the recipe to a tee!
Very good recipe all the kids love it.
The only change I made was instead of buillion cubes i use chicken base-to taste. Otherwise, the family loved it!
Great recipe. Did not change a thing. Easy and delicious!

overall, really good. I adjusted the spices like suggested in other reviews (have a salt free penzeys blend, mural of flavor, that we love). cooked the turkey in with the veggies and just made the gravy by itself. everything else was the same, and this turned out great. will definitely have it again
Good but too dry
The only changes I made were: used turkey drippings from leftover Thanksgiving dinner, one chicken bouillon cube, and added one orange habanero.

A delicious way to use up our Thanksgiving turkey! I followed the recipe as written, except I subbed leftover roasted vegetable medley ( onion, potatoes, butternut squash, and red pepper) for the vegetables listed.
Very simple to make. Delicious i did change some of the spices added sage and garlic powder thyme and pepper very good

Thank you Linda for a great recipe. I love it when people put themselves out there and share a recipe and we get to read how others interpreted it. What a great resource.
I did some 'adjusting' if you will. First off, how can you mince onions and not add a couple of cloves of garlic! I went for the 6 minute pre-cook of the bottom shell and was quickly reminded of pastry 101, it shrinks! So if you do pre-cook the shell, don't trim off all the edges until you fill it with the goodies.
There were a few comments on it being bland. Once again, cooking 101, taste for seasoning throughout the process! I increased the oregano and pepper and snuck in a generous 'sprinkle' of poultry seasoning. To up the saltiness I used Costco's Better than Bouillon and sprinkled a little grated Parmesan cheese on top before adding the top shell. To get a good thick sauce I used my flour shaker over the veggie mix as it was softening. That with the flour in the turkey (at least 2 cups worth!) did the trick. Next time I might use a bit more milk.
It was great yesterday and I have to imagine it will be even better the day after
This recipe is the bomb I use Turkey stock by kitchen basics gives filling a richer flavor I also prebake the bottom crust. Love this recipe made it five times
Great recipe I use frozen peas and carrots cuz I hate cutting up carrots, and the peas taste good added to it , sister always wants me to visit with some when I make it lol

An easy meal that makes a wonderful comfort food. Varying the recipe is also easy as you can add green beans, corn or whatever other vegetables you like. The secret is to make the final mixture thick enough before adding it to the pie crust. You want it so it takes a few seconds to ooze through a slotted spoon. This will ensure that you don't have a pie that is too runny.
delicious

Yummy!! I made it as a casserole using puff pastry. Reduced the amount of potato, almost doubled the amount of turkey, doubled the milk and added a tablespoon+ of Poultry Seasoning. Will definitely be making this again! Will be my go to after every turkey dinner. The only thing I regret is not saving the turkey gravy to serve with it.
I added some frozen peas. Otherwise, I found the ingredients perfect. Would definitely make it again!

I boiled up the carcass and left over turkey from thanksgiving then took all the fat, skin, and bones out.I used the meat for the pie and the stock from the boiled turkey instead of water and added chicken bouillon cubes to taste. It was delicious, my guests raved over it. I actually tripled the recipe because there was so much meat and froze the extra uncooked pies - they cooked perfect at a later time

This a great starting place for me. I followed the recommendations of other reviewers and pre-baked my crust for 10 min, it was perfect. I used the turkey gravy packet for my sauce and did use these spices but doubled. And my family likes things with more punch so I added a dash of crushed red pepper, good bit of black pepper to gravy and veggie mix. They loved it!

This recipe is a winner! I should have made two. I used Thanksgiving leftovers, turkey and veg. Substituted turkey stock for water and bouillon, but basically followed recipe. It was delicious. My husband and daughter loved it

So yummy!! I added peas and a little more turkey than was called for. I took the advice from another review and cooked the pie crust for 10 minutes before adding the ingredients and it came out perfectly. Will definitely make again.

It was simple to do and I added some of the left over green beans. Made more gravy like one of the reviewers recommended. Added some left over white wine and a dash of cayenne pepper and some dried thyme and some fennel salt for another flavor note. It was excellent.
used tsp herbs de provence for seasoning...easy and flavorful
I forgot to pre-bake the crust! You definitely need to do it because the soggy crust will stick to the bottom. Next time I'll prebake. Uggh.
Great for left over turkey.
I never make pies and my son can't get enough of this! Thank you!! I don't eat dairy and meat so I substituted milk with soy and butter with margarine.

My family and I are addicted to this simple recipe. I have everything prepared before I assemble my pie. I keep the recipe just the way it is. I use my foodsaver and always keep 1 1/2 cups turkey breast on hand.

I made this but with a fee changes. I pretty much doubled the vegies and tripled the meat, also added a cup of frozen peas. Peas made the pie in my opinion. I hate oregano, so I used rosemary and basil in its place and it was fantastic!
Delicious! Followed recipe but added about 1/4 tsp poultry seasoning, & used garlic salt. Also added 1/2 c. peas. YUM!

I followed the recipe except I used a 9 inch pie shell from Tenderflake instead of making my own. Much easier! But this was a fun, easy recipe to follow, and assuming you have left over turkey, you`re sure to have all other ingredients you need too.

I made slight changes since I didn't have chicken bouillon. I used a cup of water and a can of progresso chicken noodle light soup. 2 tsp sage, 1 tsp garlic, 1 tsp poultry seasoning, and 1 tsp basil were also added. I didn't use celery but added French beans instead since that was what was in my fridge. I also only used 2 potatoes since the soup had noodles. Yum!

The first time I made this it seemed a little complicated but my husband loved it so I tried it again. It's simple once you get the hang of it and you can add different veggies or more or less of whatever you like. We add peas instead of celery and double up the recipe so there's plenty to share.

This pot pie was excellent. I used smoked turkey left over from the holidays, added one more carrot and green peas. The peas were added along with the turkey mixture to the vegetable mixture. Also, the pie crust started to brown after 5 minutes in the oven, so I topped it with foil. Overall, this pot pie was delicious and worth saving.

"Best pot pie you've ever made!" according to my 19 yr old daughter. I used chicken, because that's what I had. I'm sure it would've been just as tasty with turkey. Followed recipe as stated, besides the meat switch. I didn't see anything needing to be changed.
Love this recipe! This will definitely be my go-to pot pie recipe! I followed the instructions with no variations and it turned out perfect. The filling was creamy and tasty!
Yes, loved it, I used mushrooms since we didn't have potatoes, I had some extra homemade crust that I used to make the pie. however we all agreed that we you could also do this local-style over rice.

Great way to use leftover turkey! Made it with the following adjustments: used only1-1.5 potatoes, added a carton of fresh mushrooms, instead of making broth I used 2 cans condensed chicken soup and 1 can chicken broth; used Pilsbury pie crust and baked bottom crust first for 6 min; didn't leave pie in much longer after the first 20 mins of baking time.
Awesome! I doubled the wet ingredients. Love having extra sauce and used puff pastry. Yum!

Delicious! My family devoured this recipe. I made my own crust with a recipe from the site, and it turned out great. I used a little more carrot and potato than it calls for and left out the celery, because I didn't have any. A great way to use up leftover Thanksgiving turkey!
I used sweet potato instead of white and thickened the gravy a bit more. I will make this again and add bigger chunks of turkey and the vegetables as well as a little more seasoning.
I would change the Oregano for Sage....but that's just me. And I actually like Oregano! Just doesn't seem right with turkey, to me.

I added more turkey and sweet peas. I used vegetable bouillon, because I did not have chicken bouillon cubes. It came out wonderful, very tasty. Everyone had seconds. The recipe is enough for two pies. What a great way to use leftover turkey from Thanksgiving.
I have made this everytime I have cooked a turkey and it is a family favourite. Love it!

I made this recipe with leftover crockpot turkey breast, used double the meat because that is what I had left. Also used only one potato finely diced and added 1 cup of frozen peas. Turned out great. Seasonings as listed were perfect with my already seasoned leftover turkey. Thanks!

Love this recipe! It makes enough for 2 pies so I always save the filling and make the second pie the next day! Only thing I like to do different in add 1 more cup of milk and extra flower of thicken up.
This is the best recipe! I've made many times & it's always a hit with my kids! And it's good with chicken too! Awesome!!!
I really loved this recipe. I added some turkey gravy to the filling before putting the pastry topping on...just to add some moisture. What an excellent way to use Thanksgiving leftovers.
I made this for my husband and he loved it. He's a pie fundi!
My family loved it they loved it so much I have made 3 turkey pot pie

I have used this recipe so many times. Love it. WAY better than boring turkey soup! I do add something green...either chopped green beans or peas, and I use half heavy cream and milk. Other than that, perfection!
Tasted great!! I actually used less butter than called for, used smoked turkey leftovers and added about 1 cup of frozen peas. The smoked turkey flavor in the pot pie was amazing!

Yum! Great recipe! I made a couple of alterations. I added leftover string beans & broccoli from our Thanksgiving dinner. I also added the leftover gravy to the roux mixture.. I only used one top crust. This was amazing. When we were done with dinner, my husband went and finished off the rest of the casserole! This will definitely be a go to for leftover turkey or chicken.

Delicious! I made it the first time with leftover turkey from thanksgiving and it has since become my go-to for chicken pot pie (I rarely use turkey outside of November:) I still make as written except 3/4 can cream of mushroom soup & I bake the bottom crust first. Time savers: use store bought rotisserie chicken/turkey and Yukon gold potatoes...you don't have to peel them. Thanks for the great recipe!
The best pot pie evahhhh!!!!!!
It hard to mess this up I have made it at least 10 times I have not measured since the second time I made it. Family loves this meal. It's a must try!!
Delicious! I made this exactly as written except I added a bit of poultry seasoning to the filling. I also baked it a total of 60 minutes (10 at 425, 50 at 350).
Flavor was really good. I did have to add a lot more milk/cream to it and the crust absorbed most of the gravy. I would make it again but use way more cream and milk.

I really like this. I only changed it by using a can of chicken stock and water to make 2 cups. I wish I'd thought to add some peas and green beans also. Peas are in the picture here, but not in the recipe. Still very good. Will make again, with more vegetables :)

I doubled the milk and flour (forgot to add the butter to the turkey but in the end I didn't miss it at all), used 2 cups of turkey, and pre baked the crust for 5 min (although I'm not sure that was necessary). Once everything was mixed together I found it quite bland so I added poultry seasoning and more salt and pepper until I liked the taste.

This is a delicious recipe! I've never made a pot pie before this, and it is the best one I've ever had. I used a simple recipe for a homemade crust of 1.5 c flour, .5 c oil, 2 tsp sugar, .5 tsp salt, 2 tbsp milk. This mixes right in the pan and I press out with my fingers. I then make another recipe for the top and press it out on wax paper before I put it on top of the pie.
